# ServiceInput

## Example Usage

```typescript
import { ServiceInput } from "@authlete/typescript-sdk/models";

let value: ServiceInput = {
  serviceName: "My Test Service",
  issuer: "https://example.com",
  supportedGrantTypes: [
    "AUTHORIZATION_CODE",
    "REFRESH_TOKEN",
  ],
  supportedResponseTypes: [
    "CODE",
  ],
  supportedScopes: [
    {},
    {},
    {},
  ],
};
```

                                                | The flag indicating whether the nbf claim in the request object is optional even when the authorization<br/>request is regarded as a FAPI-Part2 request.<br/><br/>The final version of Financial-grade API was approved in January, 2021. The Part 2 of the final<br/>version has new requirements on lifetime of request objects. They require that request objects<br/>contain an `nbf` claim and the lifetime computed by `exp` - `nbf` be no longer than 60 minutes.<br/><br/>Therefore, when an authorization request is regarded as a FAPI-Part2 request, the request object<br/>used in the authorization request must contain an nbf claim. Otherwise, the authorization server<br/>rejects the authorization request.<br/><br/>When this flag is `true`, the `nbf` claim is treated as an optional claim even when the authorization<br/>request is regarded as a FAPI-Part2 request. That is, the authorization server does not perform<br/>the validation on lifetime of the request object.<br/><br/>Skipping the validation is a violation of the FAPI specification. The reason why this flag has<br/>been prepared nevertheless is that the new requirements (which do not exist in the Implementer's<br/>Draft 2 released in October, 2018) have big impacts on deployed implementations of client<br/>applications and Authlete thinks there should be a mechanism whereby to make the migration<br/>from ID2 to Final smooth without breaking live systems.<br/>                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |

                                                | The flag indicating whether generation of the iss response parameter is suppressed.<br/><br/>"OAuth 2.0 Authorization Server Issuer Identifier in Authorization Response" has defined a new<br/>authorization response parameter, `iss`, as a countermeasure for a certain type of mix-up attacks.<br/><br/>The specification requires that the `iss` response parameter always be included in authorization<br/>responses unless JARM (JWT Secured Authorization Response Mode) is used.<br/><br/>When this flag is `true`, the authorization server does not include the `iss` response parameter<br/>in authorization responses. By turning this flag on and off, developers of client applications<br/>can experiment the mix-up attack and the effect of the `iss` response parameter.<br/><br/>Note that this flag should not be `true` in production environment unless there are special<br/>reasons for it.<br/>                                                 | custom client metadata supported by this service.<br/><br/>Standard specifications define client metadata as necessary. The following are such examples.<br/><br/>* [OpenID Connect Dynamic Client Registration 1.0](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-registration-1_0.html)<br/>* [RFC 7591 OAuth 2.0 Dynamic Client Registration Protocol](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7591.html)<br/>* [RFC 8705 OAuth 2.0 Mutual-TLS Client Authentication and Certificate-Bound Access Tokens](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8705.html)<br/>* [OpenID Connect Client-Initiated Backchannel Authentication Flow - Core 1.0](https://openid.net/specs/openid-client-initiated-backchannel-authentication-core-1_0.html)<br/>* [The OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework: JWT Secured Authorization Request (JAR)](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-oauth-jwsreq/)<br/>* [Financial-grade API: JWT Secured Authorization Response Mode for OAuth 2.0 (JARM)](https://openid.net/specs/openid-financial-api-jarm.html)<br/>* [OAuth 2.0 Pushed Authorization Requests (PAR)](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9126/)<br/>* [OAuth 2.0 Rich Authorization Requests (RAR)](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-oauth-rar/)<br/><br/>Standard client metadata included in Client Registration Request and Client Update Request (cf.<br/>[OIDC DynReg](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-registration-1_0.html), [RFC 7591](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7591.html)<br/>and [RFC 7592](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7592.html)) are, if supported by Authlete, stored<br/>into Authlete database. On the other hand, unrecognized client metadata are discarded.<br/><br/>By listing up custom client metadata in advance by using this property (`supportedCustomClientMetadata`),<br/>Authlete can recognize them and stores their values into the database.                                                 | The flag indicating whether the expiration date of an access token never exceeds that of the<br/>corresponding refresh token.<br/><br/>When a new access token is issued by a refresh token request (= a token request with `grant_type=refresh_token`),<br/>the expiration date of the access token may exceed the expiration date of the corresponding<br/>refresh token. This behavior itself is not wrong and may happen when `refreshTokenKept` is<br/>`true` and/or when `refreshTokenDurationKept` is `true`.<br/><br/>When this flag is `true`, the expiration date of an access token never exceeds that of the corresponding<br/>refresh token regardless of the calculated duration based on other settings such as `accessTokenDuration`,<br/>`accessTokenDuration` in `extension` and `access_token.duration` scope attribute.<br/><br/>It is technically possible to set a value which is bigger than the duration of refresh tokens<br/>as the duration of access tokens although it is strange. In the case, the duration of an access<br/>token becomes longer than the duration of the refresh token which is issued together with the<br/>access token. Even if the duration values are configured so, if this flag is `true`, the expiration<br/>date of the access token does not exceed that of the refresh token. That is, the duration of<br/>the access token will be shortened, and as a result, the access token and the refresh token<br/>will have the same expiration date.<br/>                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |

                                                | The flag indicating whether the port number component of redirection URIs can be variable when<br/>the host component indicates loopback.<br/><br/>When this flag is `true`, if the host component of a redirection URI specified in an authorization<br/>request indicates loopback (to be precise, when the host component is localhost, `127.0.0.1`<br/>or `::1`), the port number component is ignored when the specified redirection URI is compared<br/>to pre-registered ones. This behavior is described in [7.3. Loopback Interface Redirection](<br/>https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8252.html#section-7.3) of [RFC 8252 OAuth 2.0](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8252.html)<br/>for Native Apps.<br/><br/>[3.1.2.3. Dynamic Configuration](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6749.html#section-3.1.2.3)<br/>of [RFC 6749](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6749.html) states _"If the client registration<br/>included the full redirection URI, the authorization server MUST compare the two URIs using<br/>simple string comparison as defined in [RFC3986] Section 6.2.1."_ Also, the description of<br/>`redirect_uri` in [3.1.2.1. Authentication Request](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#AuthRequest)<br/>of [OpenID Connect Core 1.0](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html) states<br/>_"This URI MUST exactly match one of the Redirection URI values for the Client pre-registered<br/>at the OpenID Provider, with the matching performed as described in Section 6.2.1 of [RFC3986]<br/>(**Simple String Comparison**)."_ These "Simple String Comparison" requirements are preceded<br/>by this flag. That is, even when the conditions described in RFC 6749 and OpenID Connect Core 1.0<br/>are satisfied, the port number component of loopback redirection URIs can be variable when this<br/>flag is `true`.<br/><br/>[8.3. Loopback Redirect Considerations](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8252.html#section-8.3)<br/>of [RFC 8252](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8252.html) states as follows.<br/><br/>> While redirect URIs using localhost (i.e., `"http://localhost:{port}/{path}"`) function<br/>similarly to loopback IP redirects described in Section 7.3, the use of localhost is NOT RECOMMENDED.<br/>Specifying a redirect URI with the loopback IP literal rather than localhost avoids inadvertently<br/>listening on network interfaces other than the loopback interface. It is also less susceptible<br/>to client-side firewalls and misconfigured host name resolution on the user's device.<br/><br/>However, Authlete allows the port number component to be variable in the case of `localhost`,<br/>too. It is left to client applications whether they use `localhost` or a literal loopback IP<br/>address (`127.0.0.1` for IPv4 or `::1` for IPv6).<br/><br/>Section 7.3 and Section 8.3 of [RFC 8252](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8252.html) state<br/>that loopback redirection URIs use the `"http"` scheme, but Authlete allows the port number<br/>component to be variable in other cases (e.g. in the case of the `"https"` scheme), too.<br/> |

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         | Flag that enables the [OpenID Connect Native SSO for Mobile Apps 1.0](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-native-sso-1_0.html)<br/>specification (Native SSO). When this property is **not** `true`, Native SSO specific parameters are ignored or treated as errors.<br/>For example:<br/><br/>* The `device_sso` scope has no special meaning (Authlete does not embed the `sid` claim in ID tokens).<br/>* The `urn:openid:params:token-type:device-secret` token type is treated as unknown and results in an error.<br/><br/>When set to `true`, the server metadata advertises `"native_sso_supported": true`. See [OpenID Connect Discovery 1.0](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-discovery-1_0.html#ProviderMetadata)<br/>and [RFC 8414 2](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8414.html#section-2) for background. Native SSO is available in Authlete 3.0 and later.<br/>
